channel.description: The top News headlines from The Sydney Morning Herald. For all the news, visit https://www.smh.com.au
channel.title: Sydney Morning Herald - Latest News

item.description: The simplest intervention is to limit the amount of blue light emitted from your devices, but there are products that can also help prevent skin damage.
item.title: Screen time isn't great for your skin, but these tips can help

item.description: A Canadian judge has ruled that the US extradition case against a senior Chinese Huawei executive can continue to the next stage.
item.title: Huawei CFO fails to end US extradition fight in Canada

item.description: If you suspect you or a family member has coronavirus you should call (not visit) your GP or ring the national Coronavirus Health Information Hotline on 1800 020 080.
item.title: Coronavirus updates LIVE: Global COVID-19 cases surpass 5.6 million as Australian death toll stands at 103

item.description: "No reasonable person can assert today that Hong Kong maintains a high degree of autonomy from China," US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said.
item.title: Hong Kong is no longer autonomous from China, Pompeo says

item.dc:creator: Bevan Shields
item.description: Johnson told MPs he "totally understands the public indignation" over the scandal but insisted his top aide would not be sacked.
item.title: Boris Johnson urges UK to 'move on' from Dominic Cummings scandal

item.description: The US President threatened to regulate or shut down social media companies after Twitter added fact checks to two of his tweets.
item.title: 'Big action': Trump threatens social media after Twitter fact-checks him

item.dc:creator: Darren Gray
item.description: Building products giant Boral is facing its second class action in six weeks over financial irregularities uncovered in its US windows business last year.
item.title: Boral facing second class action over North American windows operations

item.dc:creator: Aja Styles
item.description: After almost 30 years of searching the universe, astronomers using WA’s state-of-the-art telescope have finally solved the mystery of “missing matter” tracing back to the Big Bang.
item.title: Big Bang missing matter finally found in WA breakthrough needed to better map our universe

item.description: The news of the day as interpreted by our talented artists, illustrators and cartoonists.
item.title: Best of cartoons, May 28, 2020

item.dc:creator: Mike Foley
item.description: Regulators are considering urgent changes to prevent electricity retailers going broke as tens of thousands of customers defer bill payments.
item.title: ‘Financial contagion’ from coronavirus may infect electricity market

item.dc:creator: Peter FitzSimons
item.description: If the teenage Cronulla star's B sample proves positive and intentional use is proven, he will have to pay a heavy penalty. But the one to really go after is the person who presumably advised him to take these drugs.
item.title: Death-wish drug taking: Bronson Xerri allegations truly beggar belief

item.dc:creator: Melissa Cunningham
item.description: More than half of Australian general practitioners say they have battled critical influenza vaccination shortages caused by distribution problems.
item.title: Critical shortage of flu shots hits regional areas

item.description: Trivia buffs: test your knowledge with today's interactive superquiz and target.
item.title: Target and superquiz, Thursday, May 28

item.description: Free daily horoscope for each star sign from renowned Astrologer Hedy Damari. Forecasts for the day ahead in life, love and career.
item.title: Your Daily Horoscope for Thursday, May 28

item.dc:creator: Jordan Baker
item.description: A tiny proportion of the teaching workforce is being dismissed for poor performance, but principals say official data does not reflect the true numbers.
item.title: Calls to ramp up scrutiny of teacher performance

item.description: COVID has given us time to turn inwards and consider what it is about life that we truly consider important. It's not all bad.
item.title: When experts found isolation was a great thing – and that debate isn't settled

item.dc:creator: Clancy Yeates
item.description: The fund manager also said it is prepared to pump billions into infrastructure investments.
item.title: $156b fund giant IFM fears early access to super precedent

item.dc:creator: Pru Goward
item.description: The trade-offs that Bob Hawke could offer Australian workers are not available to Scott Morrison. He is right to attempt industrial reform, but it is a courageous and challenging path.
item.title: Industrial reform will be PM's Everest – it won't resemble Hawke's Accord

item.description: Exhaustive reviews stress the importance of self-determination, yet the NSW government has cut funding to a crucial voice for Indigenous families.
item.title: We can't return to business as usual: Aboriginal voices critical to child protection

item.description: Scott Morrison was re-elected as Prime Minister in 2019 with no policies. Now he plunders innovative – and successful – ideas from the ALP.
item.title: Everything old is new again as PM plunders Labor's ideas

item.description: My employer is using software to track when I’m at my computer.
item.title: Work intrudes further into the home with monitoring software

item.dc:creator: James Laurenceson
item.description: Do you stop supplying half of your Shiraz to China because the government says we need to "diversify"? You can't give up that business to pursue wine sales in teetotal India or Indonesia.
item.title: Reality check on finding new export markets: China's demand dwarfs the rest

item.dc:creator: Lyn Maccallum
item.description: Historic property sold, RSL tapestry stolen and another Matthew Flinders.
item.title: In the Herald: May 28, 1973

item.dc:creator: Genevieve Rota
item.description: Feeling nostalgic? These dance movies capture the early 2000s zeitgeist perfectly.
item.title: Five must-watch dance films from the early 2000s

item.dc:creator: Genevieve Rota
item.description: In the mood for a bingeable TV show that's pleasant, wholesome and and won't add any stress to your life? We've got five options for you.
item.title: Light and fluffy shows that'll make you feel warm and fuzzy

item.dc:creator: Samantha Hutchinson
item.description: It’s been six years since Joe Hockey and Mathias Cormann were snapped puffing cigars on a cold Budget Friday. Labor isn’t keen to forget.
item.title: Liddell, the smoking gun and cigar-gate

item.dc:creator: Jacqueline Maley
item.description: Single-parent families headed by women have twice the rate of poverty of single-parent families headed by men, according to new research underscoring the gendered impact of poverty even before the coronavirus pandemic.
item.title: Families headed by single mothers twice as likely to be battling poverty, says new research

item.dc:creator: Aisha Dow
item.description: From next week it will become even harder for people to get access to high-strength painkillers such as oxycodone and codeine.
item.title: Painkiller packs cut down to size as opioid crackdown intensifies

item.dc:creator: Noel Towell
item.description: All the men from Victoria have to do is sign feel-good agreements with China and let other people tackle the hard stuff.
item.title: Claims of Andrews 'arrogance' on delicate China ties just might stick

item.dc:creator: Tammy Mills
item.description: Almost 6000 people in Victoria have been fined since social restrictions were imposed - double Queensland's tally and four times more than in NSW.
item.title: Ahead on penalties: Victoria leads nation on COVID-19 lockdown fines

item.dc:creator: Liam Mannix
item.description: Some countries are spending billions to lock in supply of unproven vaccines, but a public health expert says it's a big gamble.
item.title: Australia avoids 'risky business' of coronavirus vaccine sweepstakes

item.dc:creator: Linda Morris
item.description: Critics say the people of NSW deserve a chance to farewell the Ultimo institution.
item.title: Powerhouse Museum reopening left a mystery

item.dc:creator: Jessica Irvine
item.description: The impact of the coronavirus shutdown is set to leave a permanent scar across the entire childcare industry.
item.title: Free childcare has shown the benefits of generous government subsidies

item.description: We need a new accord with government, unions and industry around a new set of reforms to build a sustainable recovery.
item.title: Another economic crisis and the cupboard appears bare

item.description: The finest photos from the international wire agencies as chosen by our picture editors.
item.title: The best of the world in pictures

item.description: Those sucking, slurping sounds in any other context only get me hot under the collar insofar as they make me want to upbraid someone on their lack of manners.
item.title: The worst thing about TV sex scenes? The ridiculous sound effects

item.dc:creator: Dana McCauley
item.description: Australia's policymakers were in March bracing for up to 150,000 deaths, by late May Australia had just 103 deaths.
item.title: Thousands of predicted COVID-19 deaths never eventuated - was it poor modelling or our response?

item.dc:creator: David Crowe
item.description: Industrial relations laws could go to Parliament as early as this year even if an ambitious reform plan fails get win consensus between unions and employers.
item.title: Workplace reform will not need 'perfect' deal: government

item.description: South Korea won praise for containing the coronavirus without mass lockdowns but has experienced a setback with its biggest daily infection surge in seven weeks.
item.title: Spike in South Korea virus cases shows perils of reopening

item.dc:creator: Matt Bungard
item.description: If you suspect you or a family member has coronavirus you should call (not visit) your GP or ring the national Coronavirus Health Information Hotline on 1800 020 080.
item.title: As the day unfolded: Gladys Berejiklian to put freeze on NSW public sector wages as Scott Morrison spruiks JobMaker plan, Australian death toll stands at 103

item.dc:creator: Latika Bourke
item.description: The company is blacklisted in the US and its application has created more headaches for UK PM Boris Johnson.
item.title: State-owned Chinese company bids to build second UK nuclear plant

item.description: The announcement comes two days after the World Health Organisation said it was pausing a large trial of hydroxychloroquine due to safety concerns.
item.title: France bans controversial drug to treat COVID-19

item.description: The news of the day as interpreted in the work of our award-winning cartoonists.
item.title: Today's cartoons: The illustrated news

item.dc:creator: David Estcourt
item.description: If you suspect you or a family member has coronavirus you should call (not visit) your GP or ring the national Coronavirus Health Information Hotline on 1800 020 080.
item.title: As it happened: Abattoir at centre of largest Victorian cluster to resume full operations; Andrews urges Victorians to work from home; Australian death toll stands at 103

item.description: And more goodwill from the Zoom zone.
item.title: There's nothing wrong with Tempe Station!

item.dc:creator: Paul Sakkal
item.description: The state's auditor has slammed the roll-out of a key Andrews government reform in response to the 2016 royal commission into family violence.
item.title: Family violence hubs rushed, poorly implemented: auditor

item.dc:creator: Clancy Yeates
item.description: After lagging the market for months, banks surged amid potential signs the economic damage from COVID-19 may be less dire than feared.
item.title: Banks surge in $17 billion catch-up rally

item.dc:creator: Lucy Stone
item.description: The new ethics committee will be bipartisan with both LNP and Labor councillors sitting on it.
item.title: Ethics committee to govern councillor inappropriate conduct complaints

item.description: Staff member at Melbourne hotel hosting quarantined travellers among state's eight new coronavirus cases as Cedar Meats, site of the state's largest cluster, prepares to return to full operation.
item.title: Hotel worker among new Victoria coronavirus cases

item.dc:creator: Adam Pengilly
item.description: The code is asking supporters to order life-size cut-outs of themselves to be placed in the grounds of their favourite team for the next seven weeks.
item.title: The $22 cardboard cut-out that will buy fans a seat at NRL games
